Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's evil double, Salamander, has been sucked out of the Tardis while it is in flight. The Doctor and Victoria are hanging on to the console base.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie! Jamie! The doors! We've got to close the doors! Can you do it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is hanging onto a wall roundel on the opposite wall to the doors.

Dialogue.Line: I'll try, Doctor, but I'll have to get to a better position.
That's it, Victoria. Hold on. Whatever you do, hold on!
I'm slipping!
No, no, you're not. I've got hold of you. Don't look out there. Concentrate on holding on.
I can't!
Yes, you can. That's the style.
Right, Doctor, I'm going to try and fall to the control panel.
All right, but watch the Tardis doesn't lurch again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie falls backwards onto the console.

Dialogue.Line: Made it.
Well done.
So far, so good.
You know the switch?
Aye. Found it. I'm nearly there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie reaches for the lever, then falls. He grabs on to the Doctor's coat before he slides down towards the doors.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right, they're closing!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis doors shut tight.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, well done, Jamie. You did it! That was a near thing, wasn't it? Are you all right, Victoria?
Oh, what happened? Are we safe now?
Oh yes, I think so. Salamander started the Tardis without first closing the door. He was sucked out.
Aye, and I nearly joined him.
I'm very glad you didn't. He's not in a very enviable position, you know, at the moment, floating around in time and space. Now then, where shall we go?
Oh, let's just get our breath back first before you start tearing off anywhere. Anyway, as you know the Tardis has a mind of its own. You know you can't control it.
Can't control it?
No.
We'll see about that. We'll see about that.
Here we go again.
I wonder where it'll be this time.
Yes, I wonder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's an Abominable Snowman, and it is being looked at by a grey-bearded Travers. A door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Silverstein?
Yes. Who are you?
Anne Travers. Is my father here?
Yes, he's here Come and see him, and take him away. He's a fool, an old fool.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Other exhibits in the room include a baby giraffe.

Dialogue.Line: Father? Father.
Anne, what are you doing here?
Looking for you.
Oh?
You were supposed to be meeting me.
Was I?
At the airport. Father, what is the matter? You send me a cable saying you're in grave trouble, and I have flown half the way around the world
Trouble. Yes, a great deal of trouble. And it's that thing!
The Yeti?
You're a stupid old fool, Julius Silverstein.
Oh, me the fool? You would like me to be the fool and give you back my Yeti, huh?
Well, you must, man. Don't you understand? It's dangerous.
Huh! For thirty years it stands here in my museum, and now he tells me it is dangerous.
I wish I'd never brought it back from Tibet.
Father, what has happened?
Well, he won't listen to me. This silly old goat won't listen to me. I've told him, warned him. Damn it, he knows it's a robot.
But Father, the Yeti isn't dangerous. It can't work unless it has a control unit.
But I've done it, Anne! I have reactivated a control unit.
Oh, but Father, this is wonderful news.
Is it? Yes, yes, I suppose it would be, except for one thing.
What?
The sphere. It's gone. It's disappeared! Look, you must let me have the Yeti back, Julius. Oh, make him understand, Anne.
Oh, I understand. I buy the Yeti off you thirty years ago, and now it is valuable. You try to scare me, take your Yeti back. Why? Money! You want to rob me.
All right then, I'll buy the thing back if that's what you want!
No, no, no. It's priceless. The only one in the world, and it is mine.
You fool.
Thief!
I'm not a thief.
Swindler!
Stubborn old goat!
Father!
Take him away. Out of my house.
Father, look, perhaps you've made a mistake. You've put the sphere away somewhere in your laboratory and forgotten it. You've done it before, you know.
No, I've looked everywhere.
Well, let's go home and look again, shall we? You know what you're like.
Yes, but suppose
Let's go and have a quiet dinner and you can tell me all about it. Then we'll go home and we'll look for the sphere.
All right. But I warned you, Julius, I warned you.
Get out! Take him away! Nobody destroys Julius Silverstein's collection. Nobody!
Come on, Father.
Nobody. The Yeti's mine. You can't scare me with your mad stories. Out, out, out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They leave the room. A silver sphere hovers in a window, beeping to itself. It drops out of sight as Silverstein returns to blow out the candles that illuminate his private collection. Then suddenly the sphere smashes through the windowpane. Silverstein goes to investigate.

Dialogue.Line: Travers? Travers, is that you? I am not frightened by your stupid tricks. Travers? I know it's you, I'm not a fool!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Silverstein comes round the corner and hears the beeping. The Yeti's eyes light up and it attacks the little old German Jew.

Dialogue.Line: I tell you it did. It was flashing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is eating a sandwich.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Jamie, if that light had come on, we'd have landed, wouldn't we?
Look, I'm not arguing about that.
But we're still travelling, aren't we? So how could it have done?
Look, I don't know. All I know is that thing came on. Now I've not taken to seeing things. At least I don't think I have.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria enters in a new Pocahontas style mini-dress, with her hair in plaits.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, do you like it?
What?
I found it in the chest. I think it looks very sophisticated, don't you?
Oh, yes, very sophisticated, Victoria. Go on, Jamie. Don't you?
Aye. Now look, I'm not daft you know, Doctor.
Doctor?
What?
Why is that light flashing?
Aha!
I see. Are you two playing some sort of game?
There you are. Told you so.
Well, then we are landing, aren't we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Let's hope it's somewhere pleasant.
Hey, it might even be Scotland.
Now shush. The scanner, that will tell us.
Where are we?
Nothing but stars. What does it mean?
I don't know. Something strange has happened. We're suspended in space

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Not just suspended, but being rapidly covered in cobwebs.

Dialogue.Line: Gravity?
On.
Power?
On.
Control?
Er, on.
Flight.
That's on too.
There you are, you see? I was right. It is all working.
You mean we've landed and yet we haven't landed?
Doctor.
Just a minute, Victoria. If the time lock has slipped
Doctor, look at the scanner!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The view is being covered by cobwebs.

Dialogue.Line: What is that stuff, Doctor?
I don't know. But something or someone is holding us here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An army corporal is talking into a telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Hello? Hello? Hello?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another soldier, in fatigues, enters.

Dialogue.Line: Know where the Captain is?
Yeah, he's upstairs, being chatted up by that TV bloke.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a darts board on the wall. The interview is being put onto audio tape by a smarmy man in a bow-tie.

Dialogue.Line: And finally, Captain Knight, could you tell us your own feelings about Colonel Pemberton?
Well, he was certainly a brave soldier. There's no doubt about that. He gave his life for his country, and I was proud to serve under him. Is that all right?
Oh, super. Sterling stuff! You talk in pure quotes, old boy.
Not just quotes, Mister Chorley. I meant what I said.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Corporal enters and salutes.

Dialogue.Line: Professor Travers is here, sir.
What the devil's going on? Why have I been brought here like this? Who are you?
Knight
Never heard of you. Who?
Captain Knight. OK, Corporal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Corporal leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Look, it's no good shouting at me, Professor. I didn't ask for you.
Who did, then?
Your daughter.
Anne? Just like her mother. Always interfering in things she knows nothing about.
I understood that you'd sent for her to come back from America and help you.
What do you want me for, anyway?
I don't. I consider this to be a military matter. Others disagree.
Well, you haven't had much success so far, have you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Army. What the devil do they know about it? Who are you?
Harold Chorley, London Television.
Who? What?
Harold Chorley, London Television.
Television? Never watch it. You an actor or something?
Journalist, actually. The government, in its infinite wisdom, decided only to allow one correspondent down here. The press chose me.
Oh yes?
Tell me, Professor, will you be in charge of the scientific section, or will your daughter?
Mind your own business!
And how long do you think it's going to take you to come up with the answer? One week? Three, perhaps?
Well how the hell should I know? Is that thing working?
Of course.
It's more than likely we won't be able to defeat this menace. London, in fact the whole of England, might be completely wiped out. There, did you get that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is sitting on the floor working on a control box. Victoria is sitting next to him. Jamie hands over a component.

Dialogue.Line: That's the only one I could find.
Oh. Oh yes, that'll do, Jamie, I think. Just get that in there and that'll be excellent. There we are, that should work.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands the box up to Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: What does it do?
Oh, nothing.
Oh, no.
Well, nothing yet, but it will do once we start moving again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie drops the box and the Doctor catches it.

Dialogue.Line: Do you think we ever will? We've been here so long.
Yes, of course we will, Victoria. You see, whatever's holding us must let go sometime.
Doctor, the scanner. It's clearing!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cobwebs disappear.

Dialogue.Line: The scanner's cleared!
Right. Now Jamie, give me a hand while there's still time. Plug this in.
Yes.
Plug it in there. Yes, that's right. Now listen, both of you. As soon as we land, whatever you do, don't let go. Hold on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The box is attached to the console.

Dialogue.Line: What's going to happen? We're landing
There. Now, hold tight

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a piercing noise.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's not so bad as I thought.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a big jolt, and everyone falls down.

Dialogue.Line: Is everyone all right?
Aye. What did you do?
Well, I've managed to move us on a bit. Not very far, perhaps half a mile from where we were expected to land. For the moment, we have eluded our captor. Look at the scanner, both of you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is a rounded tunnel lined with dressed stone and lit in places.

Dialogue.Line: Well, where are we?
I really don't know, Victoria. Shall we go out and have a look?
Now, is it safe?
Oh, I shouldn't think so for a moment. Jamie, I think we're going to need torches.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Victoria and Jamie come out of the Tardis, which is parked by metal security gates. The walls are tiled. There is a large metal boxed conduit above.

Dialogue.Line: Some sort of grille.
Don't say you've landed us in a prison.
It could be the dungeons of a castle.
It's so dark.
Ah, steps. Come along, be careful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go down a staircase.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, it seems to be a large room. Tiled walls, curved ceiling. Come on.
The floor seems to end here. Hey, there's a sort of trench. Look.
Hey, Doctor. Come and look at this.
What have you found, Victoria?
See for yourself.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor shines his torch on the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Covent Garden. Oh yes, of course. It's an underground station. We're standing on the platform.
Underground station?
Trains. Underground trains. A little after your time, I think, Victoria.
Is it always as dark as this?
No, no, no. It's probably the middle of the night. Come along, let's go up top. There'll be lots of light up there. Funny, isn't it?
What?
How we keep landing on your Earth!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The street exit has a metal gate across it.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, the Doctor was wrong.
Aye, it's not the middle of the night, it's broad daylight.
Just a minute. Just let me get my breath. Those stairs.
It looks like we're locked in, though.
Well, that's strange.
Doctor.
Yes?
Listen.
I can't here anything.
Oh, it is quiet. I see what you mean. The middle of London, there should be some noise.
Hey, Doctor, there's an old man over there. Let's ask him.
Yes, go on.
Excuse me. Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie reaches through the gate to touch the man leaning against it. The cobweb covered figure slides sideways to the ground, revealing a newspaper banner proclaiming 'Londoners flee! Menace spreads'.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right, it's all right.
Oh but Doctor, did you see his face? It was sort of covered with cobwebs.
Like that stuff we saw on the scanner.
Yes, yes. Now, come along.
Oh, no, no, don't let's go into the tunnel, please.
But we've got to get above ground, Victoria. Now let's try the next station. Come along.
Aye, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie jumps down into the 'trench'.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, no! Don't move! Don't touch the rails.
What's the matter?
Whatever you do, stand still! Stand still. Don't move. Keep quite still, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds a small meter over the rails.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's all right. You can relax. The electricity is off.
What was all that about?
If there had been a current running through these rails, you'd have been fried!
Hey?
Electrified. Brunched! Burnt up! Now, come along. It's safe now, I think, but we'd better be careful. Follow me

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor bends down to touch the rails.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing, Doctor?
Just confirming something. Yes, just as I thought. There haven't been any trains here for some time.
Hey, what's that over there?
It's a power cable. I wonder what it's doing down here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A row of overhead lights comes on.

Dialogue.Line: In there, quick.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hide in a maintenance men's alcove. Three soldiers approach. The sergeant is carrying a rifle at the ready and the other two a drum of cable which is unwinding as they walk past the alcove and on towards Covent Garden.

Dialogue.Line: Soldiers? I wonder what they're doing down here?
Let's go and ask them.
No. I think we'd better tread carefully. Let's go and find out what's going on first.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They follow the soldiers a short way.

Dialogue.Line: What do you want us to do, Doctor?
You follow the soldiers, but keep out of sight. I'm going to see where this cable goes to. Meet back here in a few minutes, all right?
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor heads back up the tunnel. Further along, the soldiers stop.

Dialogue.Line: (a corporal) What's the matter?
Thought I heard something.
(the sergeant) Getting a bit jumpy, aren't you, Weams?
It's no wonder, is it, Staff?
Shall we connect up the new drum now, Staff?
Yeah. All right, Corporal.
Good thing we fixed these lights.
You can say that again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A little way back.

Dialogue.Line: I can't hear anything.
Are they still there?
I think they must be moving. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria walks into a cobweb and squeals.

Dialogue.Line: I told you I heard something, didn't I, Staff?
Yeah. Come on.
I'm sorry!
It's only a cobweb.
Oh, do you think they heard?
Hope not. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But they are ambushed at the next maintenance alcove.

Dialogue.Line: Well, well, well, would you believe it? The babes in the wood.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has followed the cable to another platform and into a pile of crates, labelled Explosives. There is a beeping sound which he recognises, and he hides by the rails under the platform as a Yeti enters.

Dialogue.Line: It's no good. I can't raise them, sir.
The truck was due there twenty minutes ago.
I wouldn't worry, sir. We've never had any trouble at Holborn before. They're probably on their way back by now.
Yes, perhaps you're right, Corporal Lane. Keep trying Holborn.
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Anne Travers enters.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, hello.
This blast recorder's working now, Captain.
Fine. Let me give you a hand.
It's quite all right, I can manage.
No, no, I insist. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chorley enters.

Dialogue.Line: Now look here, Knight. I really must protest.
What's the matter now, Mister Chorley?
Professor Travers! He's being obstructive and secretive. Now I was led to believe that when I came here, I was going to be given full facilities. Look, perhaps you can help, Miss Travers?
I really am very busy, Mister Chorley.
But so am I.
There's not time for talking, Chorley. Travers is busy. Now don't worry, I'll see that you're not left in the dark.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Anne smiles as Knight bustles Chorley out of the room.
Meanwhile at Charing Cross, two Yetis are on the platform. They use a cobweb gun to smother the crates of explosives.

Dialogue.Line: All right, you two, stand over there. Keep an eye on them, Blake, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another soldier enters.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, you there. Give the craftsman a hand.
Oh, but Staff, I'm on this other job.
Don't argue, lad. Just get on with it. I want that in the Operations Room upstairs.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weams and the soldier carry the cable drum up the staircase.
Anne and Lane are working on pieces of equipment.

Dialogue.Line: How's it going?
Just fine.
What's a girl like you doing in a job like this?
Well, when I was a little girl I thought I'd like to be a scientist, so I became a scientist.
Just like that?
Just like that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Arnold enters.

Dialogue.Line: Been a long time, Staff. Everything all right?
Yes, all right, sir. Weams is just struggling up with the cable now. Come on, you two, chop chop.
In here, mate. Come on.
Any trouble at Charing Cross?
No trouble, sir. All right, lads, you can buzz off now. By the way, I brought you back a little present, sir.
Oh?
Found a couple of youngsters loose in the tunnel.
What the devil were they doing down there?
I don't know, sir. I thought perhaps you'd better chat them up, so I brought them back here.
Put them in the Common Room, Staff. I can't talk to them now. I don't want to waste any more time on this demolition job.
Sir.
Staff Sergeant.
Yes, miss.
You're sure there are only two of them down there?
Yes, miss. Why?
Well, I don't like the idea of the tunnel being blown up if there's anybody else down there.
I see what you mean, miss.
Make sure there's no one else down there. Have a word with them, Staff. I want that tunnel blown as soon as possible.
How much longer are we going to be kept here?
What's the matter then. Don't you like it here?
No, I don't. Where are we, anyway?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Arnold enters.

Dialogue.Line: All right, Blake. I'll take over now.
Right-ho, Staff.
You two, in here.
Do you mind telling us where we are?
Oh, this place has been here a long time. It were a transit camp in the Second World War.
What do you do down here?
Now, now, everybody knows what's happening. And you know very well you shouldn't have come down here. By the way, you were on your own, weren't you?
Well
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At Charing Cross, the Yeti leave and the Doctor comes out of hiding.

Dialogue.Line: You're quite sure there was nobody with you?
Look, how many more times?
Well, that's all right then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight enters.

Dialogue.Line: Clear to fire, Staff?
Yes, sir. They were on their own apparently.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What was all that about?
I suppose there's no harm in telling you. You know, you two are very lucky. We're going to blow up the tunnel.
What?
That's what we were laying the cable for.
The Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Victoria have been locked in.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, let us out! Let us out!
It's no good, Jamie. They can't hear. What have we done?
Not we, Victoria. Me. I'm the one that's to blame. I should have told them about the Doctor.
A doctor? Well, if he was anywhere near those explosives when they went up.
Yes, sir. Don't you think I should go and have a look, sir? The youngsters said he was following the cable.
Yes, you'd better.
Sir.
Oh, and Staff, take someone with you.
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Arnold leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Sir?
Yes, Weams?
This blast recorder ain't working, sir.
Rubbish. Miss Travers checked it.
Well, it ain't registered, sir.
He's right.
But it fired. Look at the circuits. You can't have an explosion without a blast, can you?
No, sir.
Well, come to think of it, we didn't hear anything either. We should have heard something, even at this distance.
Yes.
Sir, this Doctor bloke who's in the tunnel. He could have tampered with the charges, you know.
Sabotage. I think it's time we had a chat with those two youngsters.
You mustn't blame yourself, Jamie. After all, the Doctor did tell us to be careful. Now we still don't know who these people are.
No, we don't know anything, except the Doctor might have been blown to kingdom come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight enters.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor, is he?
Sit down, both of you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Anne and Chorley enter.

Dialogue.Line: Is it bad news, then?
Oh, no. Well, at least, we hope not.
We don't know for the moment. I've sent a couple of men along the tunnel to investigate. But that's not why I came in here. You three are up to something, and I mean to find out what.
We're up to something? Now just a moment. Suppose you tell us first just what's going on down here.
How did you get into the tunnel? Or let me put it another way. Where did you break in?
We didn't break in.
But you must have done. All the stations are sealed, aren't they?
We just arrived. We were brought here.
Sir, Lane's got Holborn on the line. Sounds like trouble.
Yeti?
Could be, sir. Something's up.
Okay, Weams.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight leaves with Weams and Chorley.

Dialogue.Line: Yeti? Did he say Yeti?
Hello? Hello, Holborn? This is HQ to Holborn. Can you hear me? Not a sausage. O'BRIEN: There must be someone manning the phone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight, Weams and Chorley enter.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, Lane, what gives?
Well, it's just firing at the other end, sir.
Firing?
Yes, sir. Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sounds of weapons fire, a voice then a scream and silence.

Dialogue.Line: Great stuff.
Hello, HQ to Holborn?
What happened, Lane?
Well, it was difficult to hear, sir. I think the truck was late getting there
Then what?
Well, they must have got the ammo unloaded, sir, because he says they were jumped when they were moving.
Take O'Brien and a couple of the others.
Sir. Come on, mate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lane and O'Brien leave.

Dialogue.Line: Here, you're not going out there?
Yes, Mister Chorley. Want to come? Report some action first hand?
Well, I don't think I'd better get in the way. I, er, I think I'd better stay here, don't you?
Yes. Yes, I think you better had.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The crates have been destroyed inside their cobweb cocoon.

Dialogue.Line: There hasn't been an explosion, Staff.
I can see that, lad. Here.
No sign of that Doctor bloke.
No. Here, what do you make of this?
It's our detonator, all right. It's fired, too. Here, hang on a minute. All the ammo, Staff. If it's fired, then why didn't
Yeah, why isn't this tunnel blocked? No damage at all. Yet something blew up here.
It's obvious, innit? It's been got at.
Where's that Doctor? That's what I'd like to know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Professor Travers is at his work bench, examining internal circuitry of a Yeti control sphere.

Dialogue.Line: Father?
Hmm?
The soldiers have found two youngsters in the tunnels. They seem to know a great deal about the Yeti.
Oh?
They know they're robots.
What?
They know about the control spheres, too.
But they can't have. I mean, the public were never told.
I know.
Where are they?
Don't you see it makes sense, Victoria. If the Yeti are in London, then the Intelligence is here too.
What, you mean controlling them?
Aye, and not only them. Look, it must have been the Intelligence that got hold of us in space, and it must have brought us here.
Oh, but why?
I wish I knew. Revenge, perhaps.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers and Anne enter.

Dialogue.Line: Well now, you've got some explaining to do, haven't you?
We have? Now look here.
Now, now, just what do you know about the Yeti?
Quite a lot, but before we go into all
And the spheres? Where'd you find out about them?
That's none of your business. I'd just like to
Who are you?
I'd like to ask you the same question.
Wait a minute, Jamie! I'm Victoria Waterfield. And that's Jamie McCrimmon!
Father?
But it can't be. Why, that's over forty years ago.
What's going on here?
Oh Jamie, don't you recognise him? It's Professor Travers.
So it is! Professor Travers! Here, hasn't he got old? Oh, but we're very pleased to see you, Professor. Very pleased.
The time machine. It was all true then?
The Tardis you mean? Aye, of course it's true. Hey, do you know what's happened to the Doctor?
Oh, is he safe?
Isn't he with you?
No, he's in the tunnels. Arnold's gone to look for him. Father, what is going on?
Oh dear, I do hope he's all right. Come on, Jamie. Let's go and find out if he's got back yet.
Father!
Eh? Victoria, try and explain to Anne, will you? It's all right, Victoria. You were born. I mean. She was born years before I was!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers and Jamie leave.

Dialogue.Line: A time machine.
Oh, dear.
And the Captain's been gone about twenty minutes, you say?
Yes, Staff.
Must have been quite a battle. I should think we've lost those chaps bringing back the ammo.
Well it's to be hoped you're wrong, Mister Chorley. All right, Blake, you can stand down now. You too, Weams.
Right-ho, Staff.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Travers enter.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Sergeant. The Doctor, is he all right?
He weren't killed in the explosion, if that's what you mean.
Oh, thank heavens.
For the simple reason that there weren't no explosion.
What?
Somebody had tampered with it, and it's my guess it was this Doctor feller.
What rot, Arnold. The Doctor's a friend of mine. He's the one man that can help us.
Oh is he now? Well, he weren't nowhere to be seen. He'd disappeared.
Do you think the Yeti got him?
No.
What makes you so sure?
Dunno. Just a hunch. Hey, wait a minute, where d'you think you're going?
He may be lying injured.
No, we'd have found him. Unless you know where he is?
I might.
Take me to him, could you?
Aye.
Right, well come on, lad.
It flies? Through time and space?
Not exactly flies. Well, it's difficult to explain.
Not half as difficult as it is to believe.
Your father believes it.
Yes. Yes, he seems to. And you met him, when was it you said? In 1935? In Tibet?
Yes.
You couldn't possibly have. You're no older than. But you seem to know about the Tibet business. Why didn't my father tell anyone about this Doctor friend of yours and his Tardis?
You're his daughter, and even you find it difficult to believe. So how would other people react?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chorley enters.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, sorry to barge in. Left my typewriter in here, and I want to knock up a quick piece about this mysterious Doctor chap. Hey, a bit of a turn-up for the book, wasn't it? Any theories?
On what?
On what the Doctor and these two kids were doing in the tunnel.
Mushrooming?
No, seriously.
Ask a silly question.
Hasn't she told you anything?
Nothing that you could print, Mister Chorley.
Oh, for goodness sake, why is everybody being so evasive? Why won't anybody answer any questions?
Perhaps they're afraid you'll interpret them in your own inimitable style.
And what does that mean, pray?
It means you have a reputation for distorting the truth. You take reality and you make it into a comic strip. In short, Mister Chorley, you are a sensationaliser.
You smug little redbrick university
Don't say it, Mister Chorley. I have a very quick temper and very long claws.
There's no sense in us losing our temper, Miss Travers. I'm sorry that my journalistic style doesn't appeal to you, but there are millions of people it does.
Yes, the gutter press has a very large following.
Yes, it does. It does indeed. And you'd do very well to remember that, because I intend to print all the facts when we get out of here.
If we get out of here. The Yeti, remember?
I'm not forgetting. In fact, I think our little friend here could tell us a few things about them. It was quite a coincidence, wasn't it, you three pitching up when you did.
What do you mean?
Ah, don't give us the innocent bit, love. You know very well that the Doctor sabotaged that explosion.
Mister Chorley, what are you talking about?
Arnold's just come back and confirmed there was no explosion in the tunnel, and the only person who was in there, as far as we know, was your Doctor friend.
If the Doctor did stop it, he had a very good reason.
Yes, well we'll find out soon enough, because Arnold's just taken the lad back in to hunt him out.
Jamie's gone into the tunnel?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Captain Knight and a party of soldiers have salvaged some supplies from Holborn. On their way back they are attacked by Yeti. Lane leads a rearguard action as Knight supervises construction of a barricade of ammunition crates across the tunnel.

Dialogue.Line: Right, Thompson, that's the best we can do. Now go and tell the Corporal to get the men back here as fast as he can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gunshots.

Dialogue.Line: No. No, you're too late. Stay where you are. Lane! Lane! Fall back! You'll never hold them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Further along the tunnel, Lane and two soldiers are firing at two Yeti. The bullets have no effect.

Dialogue.Line: Will nothing stop them?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One soldier falls, and the Yeti kill him.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lane and O'Brien retreat, firing.

Dialogue.Line: Right, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: O'Brien's rifle jams, so he uses it as a club. The Yeti knock him down and use their web guns on him. Lane fires and runs back to the barricade.

Dialogue.Line: We couldn't hold them, sir. They're coming, two of them! They got O'Brien and Cocksey. Nothing stops them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a voice behind them.

Dialogue.Line: It's Staff Arnold.
Yeah, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight and Lane go back to Arnold and Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Captain?
Yeti.
They got two of us.
And the ammo detail. They're all gone.
What's the plan then?
I brought a load of explosives down from Holborn. I'm going to blow it and them with it.
Taking a bit of a risk, aren't you, sir?
Yeah, I know.
Hey, look. What's happening?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Yeti are using their web guns on the barricade.

Dialogue.Line: What are they doing?
Looks like the cobwebs.
Cobwebs or not, I'm going to blow it sky high. Get back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight aims his rifle at the barricade and fires. There is the sound of an explosion and a blinding light.

Dialogue.Line: What's that noise?
The boxes are pulsating!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cobweb has absorbed the blast. The Yeti are untouched.

Dialogue.Line: Get back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But there are two more Yeti approaching from their rear.

Dialogue.Line: Chorley's an idiot, telling Victoria the boy's gone. Those two are all that child's got in the world.
I asked her to make some tea. Thought it would take her mind off things.
Oh, good idea. Oh, switch the soldering iron on, would you?
Father? Have you ever seen this Tardis?
No, no, I can't say I have.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria is outside the door, and overhears them.

Dialogue.Line: It all sounds a bit far-fetched to me. You know, I think the Doctor's at the back of all this.
What do you mean?
Doesn't it strike you as odd that on the two occasions you've encountered the Yeti, you've also come across the Doctor?
Well?
Well, it's obvious. He controls them!
Oh, but surely. What? Oh, tea. Thank you, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria has entered.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, aren't you having any?
No. I think I'll go and lie down for a bit.
Yes, good idea.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Do you think she heard?
No. In any case, what you say is nonsense, Anne. I saw the Doctor defeat those robots and save Detsen Monastery. He wouldn't do that if he was in league with them, now would he?
No, no, I suppose not. In a situation like this one imagines all sorts of things.
This waiting's getting on my nerves. Why the heck don't they do something?
Steady, lad. We'll know soon enough.
We can't just stand here. Can't we make a run for it?
We wouldn't stand a chance, not with them switched on.
How do you know that?
It's all right, sir. The Professor's vouched for him. Understand he knows a great deal about these robots.
See, you have to find out. (beeping sound) What's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Yeti leave.

Dialogue.Line: They've left us behind.
What made them do that, I wonder?
Couldn't say, sir. But I don't think we should stay to find out.
Yes, you're right, Staff. Come on. Let's get back.
Wait. Can we not just see what they're up to?
No! If there's one thing that I've learned, it's never push your luck. Now come on.
Tibet? Tibet? You're joking.
That's where old Travers says they come from. He reckons they're Abominable Snowmen.
Well, he's off his chump, ain't he? How'd they get here in the first place?
Come through the post, don't they?
Nah, seriously. Outer space, that's where they come from. Well, that's what I reckon, anyway.
Oh do leave off. You've been reading too many kids' comics, you have.
All right then, Corp, where do they come from?
It's a foreign power, ain't it? Bacteriological warfare, that's what that stuff is in the tunnels.
What, that fungus stuff?
Yeah. And them Yeti are some sort of new weapon. Well, a sort of robot army.
What, you mean it ain't real then?
Well of course they ain't, you nit! Otherwise we'd be able to knock 'em out with the small arms, wouldn't we?
Yeah. Nothing hardly touches them, does it?
Not unless you can cop 'em straight between the eyes. Then they've had it.
Yeah, well that'll take some doing. I mean, I'd have a job just holding me arm steady if one of them ugly creeps came at me, wouldn't I?
Yeah. I wish we had some more hand grenades, cus they're the things that seem to stop them dead in their tracks.
Yeah, but we ain't got any, have we?
It's a pity that ammo truck they stopped at Holborn had all the gear in.
Stone me! Here, we ain't got much of a chance if we come up against that lot, have we.
Not with the funny old crowd we got down here with us. You got civvies, RE's, REME.
Here, watch it, mate.
The lot. A right old Fred Karno's Army, innit? Still, not to worry, me old son. Not the end of the world, is it. Want some more tea?
Yeah, all right mate.
Well, move then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weams glances at an illuminated map of the underground.

Dialogue.Line: Here, Corp, look at this.
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The rail lines are marked in white and the web fungus is tracked by a black line which runs around the Circle Line. The Jubilee hadn't been built yet.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, crikey. That's what comes of talking about it.
It's that fungus stuff, it's moving again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Euston Square flickers out and the black line moves on Kings Cross.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Anne, come and do this for me, will you?
All right, father.
It's my hands. Can't control them! Getting old, that's my trouble.
Don't worry.
I can't help it. I feel responsible somehow. If only the Doctor would turn up. I'm sure he could help us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A knock at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me, sir.
Eh, what?
That fungus stuff. It's on the move again. Euston Square's gone.
Come on, let's have a look.
Is it on the move again, Weams?
Yes, sir. Kings Cross has gone out, and it's moving on to Farringdon.
It's never moved as fast as this before.
Hasn't moved at all the last three weeks, Miss.
What started it up again all of a sudden?
Can't say.
Strange, isn't it, that all this should happen on the very day that your mysterious Doctor friend turned up?
He hasn't turned up.
Precisely. He could have sent those kids in here as spies.
Rubbish! Would Jamie go away and leave Victoria, if he didn't intend coming back again?
Excuse me, sir, but where is the young lady?
Oh, in the Common Room, I suppose.
No, she's not, cus I went in there when I was looking for you.
What? Well, where is she then?
Jamie? Doctor? Jamie? Doctor?
Not a sign of her.
We looked everywhere.
Well, then, she must have gone
Like I said, a couple of spies.
Look, sir. The fungus, it's moving again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The black line is closing in on Liverpool Street.

Dialogue.Line: I hope the Captain and Staff Arnold aren't anywhere near that little lot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A voice in the distance is singing scales.

Dialogue.Line: What is it, sir?
Quiet! Listen. Quick, get in there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldiers hide in an alcove.

Dialogue.Line: (sings) Sosban fach yn berwi ar y tân, Sosban fawr yn berwi ar y llawr, A'r gath wedi

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Evans passes the alcove and Arnold steps out behind him.

Dialogue.Line: Soldier.
Well, there's a sight for sore eyes.
Are you stark raving mad?
Aye, well, I always sing when I'm scared, see.
Stand to attention when you're talking to an officer. Name and last three.
Six oh
Shush!
(sotto) Six oh one Evans, sir.
Evans? Anybody know him?
Oh, I'm not one of your lot, sir.
Then what are you doing down here?
Trying to get out, Sarge.
Don't try to be funny with me, lad. How did you get down here in the first place?

Driver on the ammo truck to Holborn. Got jumped, we did. Quite a dust up, there was. Couldn't get past them hairy creatures, see? Been wandering for hours. Lost, I was. I tried one way, but there seemed to be some sort of cobweb muck moving down the tunnel.
Moving? Are you sure it was moving?
Well of course I'm sure, sir. Sounds daft, I know, but it seemed to be following a Yeti that had a kind of pointed glass thing in its hands.
Was it shaped like a pyramid?
Well, I suppose it was, really.
Well, that's it. Smash the pyramid, and you put the Intelligence out of action.
What Intelligence?
Whereabouts did you say this happened?
Kings Cross, Staff.
What?
Headquarters, sir. HQ may be in danger.
Yes. We'd better get back as soon as we can.
No, look.
You heard what the officer said. Now come on.
Look, I came down here to find the Doctor. I'm not going back till I have.
Now look here
No, I'm not going. And if I get a chance to smash that pyramid, I will.
That's quite a risk you're taking.
Aye, but it's me that's taking it.
All right, it's your neck, chum.
Sir?
Yes?
I'd like to volunteer to go with the young gentleman, sir.
Well, you're not one of my lot. All right. Come on, the rest of you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldiers leave.

Dialogue.Line: Thanks.
Don't be daft, boyo. First chance I get and I'm skipping.
Liverpool Street gone now, sir.
But still no movement on the southern section.
No sign of the Captain yet.
Once this stuff joins up, we've had it. Why don't we try and get out now, while we've still got a chance?
Sounds like a very good idea to me.
No, no. The decision to evacuate this fortress must be taken by Captain Knight.
Yes, but where is he, Father? He's been gone for ages.
Let's just hope he's not on the Circle Line.
Here we are, then. Cannon Street. Circle Line.
We've gone miles out of our way.
I told you I didn't know one tunnel from another, didn't I?
Why didn't you tell me about these maps before?
You never asked. Who wants to find a Yeti anyway?
Monument next then Tower Hill. Come on, we must find that pyramid.
Oh, thank heavens you're back, Captain.
Where are the other men?
Gone.
Captain, come here. The southern section's on the move. Charing Cross and the Temple have gone.
Look, Weams says there's a danger we might be cut off. Now don't you think it would be a very good idea if
If you want to leave, Mister Chorley, no one's stopping you. Now, when did all this happen?
Just after you left. Still no sign of the Doctor?
None.
Or the girl?
Has she gone too?
Yes.
That means all three of them are out there, sir.
Yes. But where?
Doctor? Jamie?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria is lost. A figure in the darkness hears her and hides as she goes past.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
I think we've had it, Corp.
Yeah, that stuff's got us trapped, all right.
Captain? Look, I know it seems hopeless, but if we could find the Doctor I'm sure he could help us.
Perhaps. But I'm sure that he must be dead by now.
If any of those three are on the Circle Line, sir, they've had it.
Captain Knight? Captain Knight! Cannon Street and Tower Hill have gone now.
That just leaves the Monument.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Evans cover their ears as the high-pitched noise echoes through the tunnels. The web closes in, pulsating and getting brighter.

Dialogue.Line: We've got to get to that archway.
There's something coming through. Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Yeti walks out of the web carrying a small pyramid.

Dialogue.Line: The pyramid! Shoot the pyramid!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Evans shoots at it twice but misses.

Dialogue.Line: The pyramid! Get it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two more misses.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, man, try again!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Evans shoots one more and the pyramid goes Boom! The Yeti stands still but the web keeps moving.

Dialogue.Line: But we've destroyed the pyramid. It doesn't work!
Let's get out while we can.
But you shot it!
Don't argue, come on,

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Yeti moves again with the web. Jamie and Evans run for the archway.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Doctor, is that you?
One moment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone say Hi! to  Nicholas Courtney as Alistair Lethbridge-Stewart. Hooray!

Dialogue.Line: Victoria!
Oh, Doctor, thank goodness I found you. Are you all right?
Well.
Who's this?
Well, you see, Victoria.
Well before you begin this rapturous reunion, there are one or two questions I'd like answered. For a start, is there anyone else down here playing hide and seek?
Well
Well, yes. Where is Jamie, Victoria?
He came out to look for you.
Out? Out from where?
The fortress at Goodge Street.
Goodge Street? Hang on, are you anything to do with Travers and his daughter?
Travers? What do you mean, Travers?
It's the same man we met in Tibet. I've come to warn you. He thinks you're responsible for the Yeti.
Me?
Oh, does he? The plot thickens, doesn't it? I think it's time I got you two back to HQ. Lead on.
Come along, Victoria.
Well, that's it. The whole of the Circle Line gone. We're completely hemmed in.
Yes, we can't get out, and no one can get in. Not very healthy, is it?
Excuse me, sir.
Yes, Corporal, what is it?
That girl's turned up again, sir, and that Doctor feller you was looking for.
Oh, him?
Yes, Staff. They was brought in by a Colonel.
A Colonel?
Where did he spring from?
I don't know, sir.
I suppose I'd better show my face. Where are they?
Corporal Blake's got them in the Common Room, sir, under guard.
Anne, you'd better fetch your father. He'll want a word with the Doctor. And you carry on here, Staff.
Sir!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight, Lane and Anne leave.

Dialogue.Line: Here, Staff, this Colonel, where'd he come from? What's he doing here?
Don't ask me, lad. It's turning into a proper holiday camp, this place.
You're sure?
Yes, yes, I'm quite all right, Victoria. I was just knocked out by the explosion a bit, that's all.
Where did the Colonel come from?
Well, I don't know. When I came to, there was no sign of the Yeti, so I wandered around for a bit and then, as I was on my way back to you, he suddenly popped out from nowhere.
How did you find out about the Intelligence?
When I saw the Yeti, I put two and two together. And then now you say Travers is here, well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight enters.

Dialogue.Line: Afternoon. Captain Knight?
Afternoon, Colonel?
Lethbridge-Stewart. Expect you're wondering who the devil I am, eh?
Well, as a matter of fact, sir, yes.
Well, I couldn't tell you before but you're a bit cut off down here, aren't you? I'm taking over from Pemberton. Sorry about him. Very fine soldier.
Taking over? I see. Well, excuse me, Colonel, but have you got any
Authorisation? Yes, of course. Here are my papers. Glad to see you don't take things at face value.
All right, Blake. You can fall out.
Sir!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blake leaves.

Dialogue.Line: How did you get in, sir?
Holborn. Ammunition party. Got badly beaten up. All the men dead, I'm afraid.
Not all. Evans managed to escape.
Evans?
The driver.
Oh, yes.
Evans didn't mention any other survivors.
No, well, it all got a bit confused. Driven into a side tunnel, myself. After that, got a bit lost, and then found this Doctor.
Yes, I was wondering when you where going to get around to me.
Yes, well, the Professor's spoken for him. We do know a little about the Doctor already.
I see. In fact, more than you do about me, eh?
To tell you the truth, sir, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers bursts in.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Who?
Oh, my dear fellow, am I glad to see you!
My word, it is. It's been a long time.
Professor, I'm told you know this man.
Huh? I'd have thought that was obvious. And if it comes to that, who are you?
Colonel Lethbridge-Stewart. New C.O. So you can vouch for the Doctor here?
Well, of course I can.
And what about this girl?
Oh, she's on my staff.

We've got lots to do, Doctor. Time's running short. Need your help. Captain Knight, I'll take him straight down to the lab. Now come on, Doctor. You'd better come too, Victoria. Things are getting a bit desperate, and I've got an idea

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers, the Doctor and Victoria leave.

Dialogue.Line: It would seem that the Professor's in charge down here, Captain.
Yes, well, he does have a job to do, sir. I think it's best to let him get on with it, don't you?
Yes, well as I say, when I came to there was no sign of the Yeti, so I wandered around a bit, got lost and saw the fungus.
You've seen it, then?
Oh, foul stuff. Oh, it was the Intelligence, all right.
Not me, then?
Huh? What do you mean?
From what Victoria said, you had one or two suspicions about me.
Rubbish, my dear fellow. Whatever gave you that idea, Victoria? Pah! Never heard anything so ridiculous in all my life.
So you did hear us talking, then?
Yes.
Oh, that. Well, it was only just idle chatter. Oh yes, it was the Intelligence that brought you here, all right.
But why? That's what I can't understand. Why?
Yes, well, you've given it the slip, Doctor. It doesn't know where you are yet.
I hope it hasn't caught Jamie.
Saint Pauls.
We're on the Central Line, all right.
Right, come on
Wait a minute.
What is it?
Nothing. Want a bar of chocolate, that's all. Got sixpence?
Ach, don't be daft! Those beasties might be right behind us. Now come on!
All this walking. Shouldn't be down here at all, you know. Driver, I am.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Evans pulls the lever the vending machine by the platform. It gives him a bar of chocolate at no cost.

Dialogue.Line: Well, there's lovely.
Don't you understand, Sergeant? I've got to get out of here!
Well I don't see as I can put it any clearer, sir. We're here at Goodge Street, right? And the fungus has gone all the way round the Circle Line.
Yes, I know that, man, but these other tunnels, the Northern Line, the Central Line, I mean, they're not filled, are they.
No, sir
They must be on a different level to the Circle Line. I mean, Wait a minute, it's absolutely simple. We go out under the stuff.
Now look, sir. You know we've already lost two men trying to do that. The influence of this fungus extends through the earth, both downwards and up. Believe me, sir, we're trapped.
But I've got to get out. You see, well, my reports are so important. I mean, the world must know what's going on down here. I mean, well, there must be a way out. The surface. What's on the surface?
Well, there's a ground level door in Cheney Street, sir, but
Of course, of course, of course. Thank you, Sergeant. thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chorley leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He's a nutter.
You're telling me. Can't even get my rank right.
Yeah, I noticed that, Sergeant.
Cheeky!
But how, that's what I can't understand. What brought the Intelligence back again?

That was my wretched curiosity, I'm afraid. You see, when I came back from Tibet, I brought quite a bit of stuff with me. You know. Broken Yeti, bits of control spheres, and things like it. Oh, the monks were only too glad to see the back of it.
Yes.
Yes, and then, my dear fellow, one of the control spheres was intact. So naturally I wanted to find out how it worked.
Oh dear.
I fiddled with the thing on and off for years, and then one day
Don't tell me. It just disappeared.
Mmm.
Yes. Well presumably, once the sphere started working, the Intelligence just homed in on it.
Yes, and with a fully functional Yeti, well, it was a ready made pair of hands for the Intelligence.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Knight enters.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry to interrupt, Professor, but Colonel Lethbridge-Stewart has decided to hold a briefing. He'd like you all to attend.
A briefing? We're not in the army yet, Captain.
Yes, I know that, Miss Travers, but now that he's taken over command, he thinks it would be the simplest way of being put in the picture.
Yes, splendid idea. Might help you too, Doctor. Now come on, I'd like to show you the layout as I've already

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers and the Doctor leave.

Dialogue.Line: If you'll just make your way to the Common Room, you'll find that he's waiting for you.
Captain.
Any news of Jamie?
No. No, I'm afraid not.
Come on, boy-o. Not far to Chancery Lane now.
You're in a hurry, all of a sudden.
Aye, well I've got it all worked out, see. Next station's where I'm getting off.
What?
Aye. Last time, the Yeti were at Holborn Station, so I reckon if I can get out at Chancery Lane, I might be able to reach my lorry.
So you meant what you said, then? You're not going back to HQ?
No, I'd be more of an hindrance, I would. Anyway, I'm not supposed to be down here. I'm a driver, I am.
Aye, there is another word I could use. Look, all you want to do is save your own skin.

Well, it's the only one I got. Look, boy-o, they don't stand a chance back there. Hop it with me now, boy, while the while the going's good. You've got to take care of Number One in this world. You'll learn. I'm getting out of these tunnels fast.
So this was the situation on the fifth. Next slide, Blake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A picture of the Natural History Museum shrouded in mist.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, yes sir, this will give you a better idea. You can see the fog, or mist, very clearly.
This mist, does it do anything? I mean, is it poisonous or anything?
No, no, no. But if anyone goes into it they just, well, they just don't come out again.
As soon as the effect of the mist was known, this whole area was cordoned off. But by the sixth, the area had expanded to include South Ken tube station. Right, carry on, Knight.
Sir. Next slide please, Blake. Now, you can see how quickly it was spreading.
Ah yes, that'd be the seventh, the day the fungus was first reported in the Underground. The tube system had to be abandoned, of course.
Any sign of the Yeti by this date?
No, they weren't sighted until the ninth. Next slide.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two Yeti.

Dialogue.Line: Ah yes. My word, I thought I wasn't mistaken. Those Yeti have changed in appearance. Look.
Why, yes. I see what you mean.
It's a sort of Mark Two, isn't it.
Yes, very interesting.
I wonder how the Intelligence managed that?
Gentlemen.
I'm so sorry.
Sorry.
Now by this time, the fungus below ground and the fog above had both extended. Slide.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An aerial picture of west London with a band of fog encircling Hyde Park.

Dialogue.Line: Ah yes, that's it. Now, notice this thin area of mist linking the two arms. I think we must now assume that this mist covers the entire area enclosed by the Circle Line.
Have you had any success against it yet?
No. We've tried chemicals, flame throwers, explosives. All to no avail.

That's why we're dependent on you three coming up with the answers. If you fail, London's finished. England itself, perhaps. Now the army will, of course, give you all the support you need. Tell me, Miss Travers, what progress have you made so far?
Well, my father and I think we may be able to jam the transmissions to the Yeti.
What we really need is some additional equipment.
Knight?
Well, sir, the main problem has been lack of communication. As you know, this fog absorbs all radio waves.
What about telephones?
All right for a while, but the Yeti soon destroyed them. We've laid a couple of lines ourselves between here and Holborn, but I don't know how long they'll last.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chorley enters. Everyone who knows him groans.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Colonel Lethbridge-Stewart.
What is it, Mister Chorley? We're in the middle of a briefing.
Yes, so I see. Did you know about this door to the surface? A helicopter could lift us all out.
Could it? Always assuming we could make contact with the outside world, which we can't, how do you imagine they would find us in that mist? Sit down, please.
Look, Colonel, I resent your tone. You seem to forget that I'm here as a representative of the Press, and as such
And as such, Mister Chorley, you are no more than a passenger. Staff, lights please.
Sir!
Right!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chorley leaves as the others mutter.

Dialogue.Line: Right, let's get down to some constructive thinking.
Ah, Weams. Weams, I'd like some information, man.
Sir?
Now would I be right in thinking there are a lot of very tall buildings in this area?
Well, the Post Office Tower, that ain't far away.
The Post Office Tower, yes. Do you think that's above the mist?
Well, I wouldn't know about that, sir, would I?
Where is it in relation to the Circle Line? Come on, man, where is it?
Well, it's about here. Crikey!
What's the matter?
Can't you see? It's that fungus stuff starting up again. I've got to tell the Colonel!
